column3121: With the help of the cities participating in Climatesmart cities assessment framework
column3123: The C-Cube is already working with 220+ cities (impacting millions of cities) across India to implement CSCAF. It is also the monitoring framework for the National Mission on Sustainable Habitat under the National Action Plan on Climate Change, Government of India. Further, it is also part of the Long-Term Low Emissions Development Strategy submitted by the Government of India to the UNFCCC as a part of NDCs during COP27. This will lead to more and more cities adopting the framework across India and leading the change to mitigate and adapt to climate change.     The CSCAF is an extensive process of data collection, analysis and reporting. Each participating city is provided with the docket of all the answers to be submitted. As the data is requested from various city and state departments, they are also provided with a template to write to respective departments for the collection of data. Overall in this process, more than 96 data points are collected from each city across the five thematic areas. Cities are provided between 3-5 months for the whole data collection process. With each data point collected, respective departments are also asked to submit documentary proof for evidence.  During the data collection process, the city is supported virtually/physically with any type of query in understanding the need for the data, where it can be collected and how to upload the data to the portal. This is to support city administration with ease of collection and filling up of data sets.   Post the collection, C-Cube checks all the data points for any anomaly and marks the same on the data portal. This query is sent to the city for them to submit an appropriate response. Upon completion of the data checking, the team analyses the data to score them as per the approved mechanism. Further, to which a city wise recommendation document is developed to support city with progressing forward in the next assessment. As well as an overall progress report is developed called, City Readiness Report, which highlights overall opportunities and challenges across Urban India.

column3110: Please completeAssumes UK Government funding continues. Definition: People benefiting from LEIA appliances = number of sales * (1 - discount for loss) * average household size. Number of sales corresponds to the annual sales in the previous calendar year as collected from GOGLA market research. The number of sales is then discounted for products that are not working or in use. Targets are cumulative.  Baseline: In 2019, we have obtained appliance specific sales data from GOGLA market research for a) refrigeration, b) TVs, c) fans and d) SWPs. The sales data are converted to people benefitting from LEIA appliances as outlined above for each of the appliances.     Individuals  From 2018- 2022 we reached 12,767,845 people with access. (reached)  From 2022-2025 our aim is to reach 4,750,000 people (target)    Companies   From 2018- 2022 we worked with 38 companies   From 2022-2025 our aim is to work with 15 companies

column1911: Working with partners including the Water Resilience Coalition on projects that contribute to Net Positive Water Impact to help people become more resilient to water stress. This is focused on water basins that are under stress in the regions and communities in which GSK operates, including India, Algeria and Pakistan.    Investing in nature protection and restoration to tackle climate change, boost biodiversity, drive health co-benefits and increase resilience to flooding and extreme weather events. GSK is a member of LEAF Coalition, the biggest public-private effort to protect tropical forests and is supporting mangrove restoration project in Indonesia.     GSK will continue to explore and confirm additional projects.

column3110: We will support multiple projects of different nature and scale. Each project will be delivered through a partner, and preferably with local implementation partners to where the project is taking place. We will align on the objectives, key milestones and KPIs of the project with the partner that will engage local communities throughout the process. Once key indicators and KPIs have been agreed, the partner will perform baseline surveys to ensure we understand the starting point and the number of people involved/impacted by the project. Progress on agreed KPIs will be tracked by the partner and communicated to GSK regularly. Details on methods, process, and type of data will vary depending on the project and the KPIs that we decide to measure.

column3112: GSK prioritises projects that have climate resilience benefits and therefore the climate risk of the community or territory is considered when selecting which projects to support. However, in most cases our project partners complete the assessment of climate risk and present the findings to GSK, which means that GSK does not have a set format or template for this assessment. In addition, the scope and process of the climate risk assessment varies from project to project depending on if the project is aimed at individuals or natural systems, if it is in an area which has already understood climate risks or not, and if the projects’ primary aim is climate resilience, or if this is a secondary aim.

column3115: Each city that joins the Cities Race to Resilience has its own unqiue context and challenges. For this reason, once a city joins the Cities Race to Resilience, they pledge to undertake a community-wide climate risk and vulnerability assessment that also includes all vulnerable communities. Thus the 'diagnostics' is contingent on each particular city, and not the initiative itself.
column3117: No, but we will consult them to validate this pledge and update it accordingly.

column3121: Each member (city) plans to use knowledge and scientific evidence available to them, including data and spatial analysis, for decision-  making and action, and outline interim targets and milestones as part of a long-term commitment for citywide action. This is unique to    each city and its location, and we expect that those cities who have committed to Cities Race to Resilience will have reported on their  actions and progress on commitments to a relevant reporting platform by the end of 2022.
column3123: This submission is not BY ANY MEANS an accurate reflection of how many people will be impacted by city resilient actions via their  commitments by joining Cities Race to Resilience.  This submission is based ONLY on the 51 cities from around the world who have already joined the Cities Race to Resilience, noting  that as an ongoing initiative, the number of cities joining will continuously grow. Furthermore, please note that - in terms of actual  impact on population - figures are generalised, i.e. population numbers have been calculated based on the latest, available census  data for each city and totalled per country. However, please note that these numbers are NOT a reliable measure of resilience impact,  as they are a) the total population of a given city NOT necessarily the actual constituents who would benefit from resilient activities or  commitments, and b) the commitments made by each city do not necessarily transfer into direct, quantifiable/measurable impacts.  Finally, please note that the population figures per city are based on what is publicly available and is not always up to date, i.e. some  city population figures are from 2016 and are therefore out-of-date. Therefore, it must be reiterated that this survey cannot and does  not capture an accurate reflection of the impact of cities joining Cities Race to Resilience.

column3121: The Global EverGreening Alliance’s Restore Africa Programme has been launched in May 2022, which aims to restore 1.9 million  hectares of land and directly support 1.5 million smallholder farming families, across six African countries – Kenya, Ethiopia, Malawi,  Tanzania, Uganda, and Zambia. The Alliance will work with its members on the ground to design the program and develop a program  plan in the following months.

column23: GRP together with USAID and with input from the Office of the U.S. Special Presidential Envoy are collaborating on the PREPARE Call to Action. As part of this Call to Action launch, 12 companies announced specific commitments to support steps that improve climate resilience for consumers and communities. This includes expanding climate information, financial products and services for adaptation, climate smart food security, and insurance. The Global Resilience Partnership (GRP), through the support it receives from USAID, will manage the Call to Action, with input from the Office of the Special Presidential Envoy on Climate.

column3110: Our number of individual beneficiaries is determined based on the annual data collection that we conduct. The members of our partnership provide us with the necessary data that we use to estimate the total number of beneficiaries. According to the InsuResilience methodology, beneficiaries are poor and vulnerable people   who could benefit directly or indirectly from a CDRFI instrument – whether it is microinsurance policyholders and their households or the number of people who could be served with the payout of a sovereign risk-financing product.

column3123: Regarding your comment on the company/meso-level: We argue that via the channel of MSMEs we are able to track the  individuals/beneficiaries behind it, as we do have the data of employees per company for every country. column3110: Build Change tracks a “safer people” metric which we will use as a proxy indicator for lives directly affected.  This metric is calculated as (safer buildings (direct) + safer buildings (indirect)) x 5, where 5 is the average  number of people living in a building unit. “Safer buildings (direct)” represents the number of buildings made safer thanks to Build Change's direct intervention, and “safer buildings (indirect)” comprises the number of buildings made safer by third parties (including partner initiatives) who have been trained by Build Change on disaster-resistant design and/or practices and buildings made safer thanks to a change of policy adopted by a governmental entity or another organization that Build Change promoted and made possible.

column650: RegionsAdapt is an initiative contributing to the Sharm-El-Sheikh Adaptation Agenda which pledges to have 100 regions with adaptation plans by 2030.
column671: Regional, national, subnational, local governments: General category for all levels of government.
column672: Regional, national, subnational, local governments dealing with agricultural, livestock, and fisheries issues: Government bodies focused on agriculture, livestock, and fisheries sectors.
column673: Regional, national, subnational, local governments dealing with energy issues: Authorities in charge of energy policy, production, and management.
column674: Regional, national, subnational, local governments dealing with public health services: Responsible for planning and delivery of public health services.
column675: Regional, national, subnational, local governments focused on finance strategies related to climate resilience: Focused on financing strategies to implement climate resilience measures.
column678: Subnational governments (states, provinces, and regions) possess varying degrees of authority tailored to their specific contexts, often encompassing entities such as Building Standard Authorities, Coastal Planning Authorities, Park Authorities, Environmental Agencies, and more.
column695: Through the CDP States and Regions Questionnaire, subnational governments confirm facing all the above climate hazards
column696: Coastal communities: Populations living in areas sensitive to sea-level rise, erosion, and coastal storms.
column697: Communities adhering to building standards for climate resilience: Those living in areas where building codes and standards focus on climate resilience.
column698: Communities in agricultural, livestock, and fisheries zones: Populations residing near or dependent on these types of industries.
column699: Communities near forests and conservation areas: Residents of areas adjacent to forests and wildlife conservation zones.
column700: Communities or regions receiving financial support for climate resilience: Those benefiting from grants, subsidies, or other financial incentives aimed at climate resilience.
column701: Communities relying on major public infrastructures: Populations dependent on large-scale public infrastructure like highways, bridges, and dams.
column702: Communities relying on specific water sources: Those dependent on particular rivers, lakes, or groundwater for their water supply.
column703: Inhabitants of cities with active climate governance: Residents of urban areas where local governments are proactive in climate change mitigation and adaptation.
column704: Populations benefiting from tailored public health services: Communities served by healthcare services adapted to the challenges posed by climate change.
column705: Populations in areas prone to coastal natural disasters: Those living in regions vulnerable to hurricanes, tsunamis, or other coastal hazards.
column706: Populations in energy-efficient planning zones: Residents of areas where sustainable and energy-efficient urban planning is a priority.
column707: Populations near or in park areas: Those living adjacent to or within national, state, or local parks.
column708: Residents of DRM-focused communities: Populations in areas with specialized disaster risk management agencies or services.
column709: Residents of areas with environmental protection measures: Those living in zones with specific policies or programs aimed at environmental conservation.
column710: Urban communities with local gardening and public spaces: Populations in urban areas that benefit from local initiatives like community gardens or improved public spaces.
column711: Subnational governments frequently formulate comprehensive adaptation plans and strategies that encompass their entire jurisdiction.

column3106: Mildly Committed: Partially Aligned with Principles
column3110: From our understanding, PLEDGE is more at Initiative Level, and tries to assess the Target to meet by 2030 whereas PLAN is at Partner level, and assess progress on how to get to the Target.     In terms of pledge, we will now update our pledge to to align to the Sharm el Sheikh Adaptation Agenda, instead of our initiative pledge of "doubling the number of regionsadapt memebers".   Hence, we are now pledging that our initiative will benefit 100 regions by 2030 however we are not yet in capacity to translate this into an estimate of individuals, as we are not able to foresee the profile of future incoming regions.    In terms of PLAN, we used to track number of beneficiaries of adaptation actions that our members are reporting through the CDP States and Regions Questionnaire and we are pushing all our regions to give us as much as possible quantified information on the number of beneficiaries. However, this was disconnected, as our PLEDGE quantifies the number of existing adaptation plans, and our PLAN quantified the number of direct beneficiaries of adaptation actions.       To address this we will now try to focus  in the PLAN SURVEY,  on communicating the size of population of regions that are covered by actionable adaptation plans , and potentially break it down by countries.

column3109: ORRAA’s mission is to build the resilience of 250 million climate vulnerable coastal people by 2030, by deploying at least USD$500 million of investment into coastal and ocean resilience through the development of at least 50 novel finance and insurance products.
column3110: ORRAA’s pledge to support the resilience of 250 million people is based on target-setting undertaken by our internal Monitoring, Evaluation, and Learning (MEL) team. This target has been approved by ORRAA’s Steering Council.     The ORRAA MEL team generates and assimilates knowledge about what works best to strengthen resilience and uses this knowledge to inform better policy and practice. It aims to help partners and grantees in delivering sustained and transformational benefits – beyond the communities directly supported by funded projects – through building and sharing evidence. To this end, the MEL team develops and manages the strategic, technical side of monitoring and evaluating, including developing the necessary MEL frameworks, tools, and indicators. ORRAA indicators measure activities and their contribution towards the alliance’s theory of change and mission. These indicators form the basis of the Alliance’s MEL procedures and are integrated into the life cycle of all ORRAA projects. The MEL team supports implementing partners in their MEL activities. The MEL team provides support through webinars, one-on-one virtual meetings, a dedicated MEL help desk and, if possible and relevant, site visits. Various templates have been developed to enable standardized reporting and learning across projects, including on indicators, and progress and final reporting. The MEL team thoroughly reviews project progress reports and supporting documents. Grantees are guided as to how to collect data using appropriate methodologies and how to minimise double counting.    A full overview of ORRAA MEL Indicators can be found here: https://oceanriskalliance.org/resource/orraa-indicator-guidance/

column3121: ORRAA’s mission is to catalyse the investment of at least US$500 million into coastal and ocean natural capital through the  development and deployment of finance products that build the resilience of 250 million climate vulnerable coastal people, by 2030.  To do this ORRAA is supporting the development of a pipeline of investible projects that deliver benefits for the Ocean and coastal  communities. As the number of projects grow, and as individual projects scale, ORRAA expects to report greater impact. This impact  will be measured through formalised M&E procedures which will be finalised in 2023.
